title: Secondary – Cycle 2– Progression of Learning - Spanish as a Third Language (2011)
subject: Languages

document.title: Secondary – Cycle 2– Progression of Learning - Spanish as a Third Language (2011)

7D9C2364DFA046CF99CB56AE11CD1B9C.description: Uses his/her errors to identify the knowledge he/she is lacking and finds solutions

A78F6CEE5509458BA30EFEB6172B1EED.description: Compares his/her accomplishments with prior ones

D8B482A3BBE747A79BA936EE6786879F.description: Finds ways to improve the effectiveness of his/her process

18298C631FC24B029A440D102D506956.description: evaluates the appropriateness of the resources used

C30D416F14584C29866DEDFFBBBBD6EE.description: evaluates the quality of his/her contribution to the work of the team and provides constructive feedback to his/her peers

012181D50A13404999412EA9CC8BBE3E.description: evaluates the effectiveness of the means implemented to overcome any obstacles encountered

07650F220B3540E7AFAC2F4BB471F1FA.description: identifies the elements that helped or hindered his/her success

00997368B46D414CA0E21532EBD66142.description: Evaluates his/her process, attitudes, finished product or the learning acquired

86AE184FB1C549AAB21A9507C526904B.description: Participates in a group feedback session about the completed task

F69C8A94EEE94D9B8D34E263ADF7FBC2.description: Pays attention to the audience reaction to his/her texts and adjusts accordingly

EFEE5C20224744C589A71FF3DC668A4F.description: Presents the text or hands it in, in the case of a production

35200C47320749E980BB073D55D83E96.description: Reviews the appropriateness of the selected communication media

F755AEBE8A104D8B887DFEF2196EA26C.description: Reviews the initial planning sequence and makes changes as required (e.g. rewrites certain passages)

24B8B14D90D74D989D453D1285FABC9D.description: Carries out the task in accordance with the instructions given

EC9163C3942E46BA8D8740660CFB3BB0.description: Consults the appropriate human and material resources to carry out the task or overcome difficulties

F877A43D4EFF4F7AA5F71134877A83C0.description: Uses learned strategies in accordance with the task

A8F45813834648789A09924709DB20ED.description: Applies ideas and knowledge of linguistic elements (e.g. rules of agreement) and cultural elements (e.g. greeting ritual)

6169A7E6DA5D4590BBF1DA87A0D1A098.description: negotiates the meaning with the other speaker

CB15D60FEDAE4413883B3EAFC95435B3.description: puts his/her ideas into textual form

D7DE31AC2EA14B25A061F021ECBDBC73.description: Communicates his/her ideas during an interaction or in a production

461F6775658045C8928FC0B2E5773B48.description: identifies the way the text is organized as part of understanding or producing a text

40B51DC99AEA4B1A886A19BA2B307CC3.description: identifies the essential elements of the content of the tex

BC0B3FFAA82D4F44AE7038EA8BF5D493.description: Constructs or reconstructs the meaning of the text

BE1435AA40D64EA2BC7AA20F354B1746.description: selects a communication medium appropriate to the task (e.g. prepares a slide show for an oral production)

8BD16A1BADBF45A3949C77CAA6A757F0.description: plans for relevant resources (e.g. brings items to class for an oral interaction)

E5DA3C62859246E995FD8270A55BDDF9.description: prepares a schedule, if the task requires it

15BA7196B6FE4BCAA6F214488413981A.description: organizes the task alone or with his/her peers and, in the latter case, identifies the role of each person

359AD98899A7439EA015BEB1BC866C59.description: collects, selects and organizes the required information

CFCF7F1DA53E4A0DACD6DD7DE37A43A5.description: Sets out the actions required to complete the task

CC5B553CAEC64B97A4C03B142A44D44B.description: Decodes or describes the purpose and other elements of the communication situation

CCD1D3B1BD044B38AFEE56D47F6BE7D6.description: Activates his/her prior knowledge (e.g. everything that he/she knows about the topic of conversation)

0461FF1F430F496193C4D692725AF6AE.description: Becomes familiar with the task’s evaluation criteria (e.g. sufficient information)

C94EF153229B4688AC85106AFC92BBB4.description: Ensures that he/she understands the purpose of the task and the instructions

C1FB3047D64D4B66B18A9F59B48CECA4.description: Pays attention to how he/she produces texts in order to identify frequently repeated errors

360AF192BE86495B856380AC4D045063.description: Asks peers for feedback on his/her production

6BD54FEAA74D48288F6F5720F51D090B.description: Encourages himself/herself so as to reduce anxiety

6391AB082AD144BEA46DE2DB7EF709A1.description: Reads the text over several times for content (e.g. relevance of ideas), form (e.g. verb agreement) and presentation (e.g. page layout)

3104B474604F437B86778D5C8F038634.description: Uses a variety of resources to produce and revise his/her text (e.g. teacher, dictionary, Internet)

F04896BC58EB424AAB9E6F93A418D5BC.description: Keeps in mind the topic of the text and the communication purpose

C087723E7D2244AF8633E37B546B869D.description: Reuses words, expressions and grammatical concepts learned in class (e.g. words from the same lexical field) in the produced tex

B2773ED41BD64FBF853F868B455DA78F.description: Uses known syntactic models to create new sentences

3A56DC868B70468CBA42E6A08935883D.description: Draws on texts he/she has heard, read or viewed and on their structure in producing his/her text

40C9B130704542D18A933EDADDC4C0D0.description: Reproduces certain model texts, notably those whose structure is familiar and repetitive (e.g. short stories, songs)

DA23F34F1F4949D983575C7C4D070FFB.description: Selects an appropriate layout and communication medium

01EC28F1BD39492CB43C6AF319C2B2F4.description: Plans the production stages and the time required

17D0880311C843D5A96F77354F22B417.description: Takes notes, selects and groups together information in preparation for writing his/her text

43D43A3DDFAC4CC5AE61C5203840BA1D.description: Participates in various forms of discussion to generate ideas or vocabulary and prepare to carry out a task (e.g. brainstorming, semantic mapping)

CF8FDA3051FF49BDAB2040F245B0BCBD.description: Congratulates himself/herself upon achieving a goal

5E05F6A207FD4DACBB5E0455B5771876.description: Adopts a positive attitude toward comprehension problems

EA0D591B63F14FA9825602294623C2E0.description: infers from the context the likely meaning of unfamiliar expressions or words

747081BCB4AD4E82A62E6A8DC4F2526C.description: works with his/her peers to find new information

F9B5F62ECCD545D0A8162C25E79C2B01.description: asks his/her peers or teacher questions to verify his/her understanding

7A61400281804F399BEB36F2BE6680C2.description: notes down elements to be clarified

B0287C5CF3BF4763964E564F26E009C6.description: reads over or listens to a text several times

967AB981D4884F249638F192B7B4642D.description: Uses a variety of techniques to overcome difficulties in understanding

CBB952D4391C4129BD4723300149B6C8.description: draws diagrams, tables or other graphic representations in order to organize information

26B37E45F7724EABA62EA08C808569CA.description: identifies the main and secondary ideas

1521AB8B50754962B9F959FCC7297B04.description: Recognizes elements of information that are essential for understanding a text

267CCE60676449AF9E43242897F0FAB5.description: makes inferences to formulate language usage rules (e.g. adverbs formed by the addition of -mente)

145E1B4DE51B4631B1636939D0C6B5B0.description: establishes links between the topic of conversation and texts that have already been heard, read or viewed

37874331E5EB4ACA827ED2759F52EBE9.description: uses known elements to infer the meaning of new or unfamiliar elements (e.g. prefixes, word order in the sentence)

AF7A7CDD3E8243978318F6431C5BDBE7.description: associates new words or expressions in Spanish with others known in the first or second language

817FAC92864B4E72AC962B3378602533.description: Takes into account prosodic elements (e.g. flow, intonation)

D4E8C93A4F704BB1AE164F5E8BC6C7DB.description: Sets a goal and takes it into account when listening, reading or viewing a text

D0BBD0B19FB145148328105CD64F96BC.description: recognizes the structure of the type of tex

0D1D3B0BBEF448FEB6FEBE34909BFAA1.description: skims texts and uses the paratextual elements to identify the topic (e.g. illustrations, subtitles, headings)

7D039A47C23B4E179998FBA98E592F91.description: Makes predictions about the text that will be listened to, read or viewed

594B62D60B404A83BB02ED8A8F299ACB.description: Uses techniques to reduce his/her anxiety and build his/her self-confidence during interactions (e.g. visualization, self-motivation)

A6452949576F49BFBA4118C9072A5F72.description: s empathetic and tries to understand the point of view of others when working in a team

5E3403EDF17840779A071AEBE8DA3447.description: Pays attention to the way he/she interacts in order to identify frequently occurring errors

4156A103D25E48809BFFEC6A88F6AA85.description: takes risks in carrying out new tasks

7D1526A3A21149F6B6ED9D9B1F94607A.description: asks questions to keep the discussion going or to further it

C3BBC259A05C47A6B45FBA5053488055.description: asks the teacher questions about the topic or task

215F3CBB7A7D4015AA2905F87891E233.description: works with his/her peers to carry out a task

93992ECA8A134A4492F64694B181AEF0.description: continues to interact even when he/she does not understand everything that is being said

80D2686C47744A0A8622CE9DD329FF63.description: confirms that he/she is using a word or phrase correctly (e.g. ¿Se puede decir…?)

39733E4CC9C5439EAC799EF37C5ADE0A.description: asks for assistance in order to learn new terms or new expressions (e.g. ¿Cómo se dice… en español?)

60DEC064A5154609A0DC14D65C32F550.description: asks the other speaker to repeat, rephrase or explain when he/she does not understand (e.g. No entiendo, ¿Puede repetir, por favor?, ¿Cómo?, ¿Disculpe?, ¿Qué quiere decir?)

794442217A674CEC978DC521D1E4F5A0.description: asks him or her to speak more slowly (e.g. Más despacio, por favor)

938D17AA7DE244E19048658ABF966DA2.description: Asks the other speaker for help

CBF5E6AABE2D407C92DC50939D89A4A2.description: Anticipates questions from the other speaker or the audience

11C5BC26662241B9ADCF0A6F08981F8A.description: uses periphrasis (e.g. el hijo de mi tía instead of primo)

C04CEBE1243B4DAF90E07A306801D0ED.description: uses a hypernym (generic term) instead of a hyponym (specific term) (e.g. mueble instead of silla)

92292E4718234079B38317CE33E9E021.description: compensates for not knowing the right word or expressions by replacing them with known words or expressions

DFA627526D004BE39A7F2572EA51CB8C.description: rephrases or starts over when communication reaches an impasse

0F8FD05E69774EFDA9717B2993F1534D.description: asks questions to verify whether the listener understands (e.g. ¿Entiendes?)

CCBE183539C348169AE9DBCDBC47A5A4.description: uses certain words to buy time when he/she does not know what to say or how to say it (e.g. pues, bueno)

473FF09A6E9240969B74B1D45BE13EC0.description: repeats what the teacher or other speaker says to formulate the beginning of his/her response

3373C28D59BA4BB5B1E52B6D64613FDB.description: Puts new terms or expressions within a context in order to remember them more easily

AD9FC934DA604036982D58EFF40BC4EF.description: Reproduces sounds, intonations and statements by repeating them out loud or to himself/herself

C3B9E0164A0A46D2BADF3348C0FBBF28.description: observes the listener’s reaction to find out if the message was understood

537C3324D3A34FA3BD6084AC3D171517.description: uses various physical actions to communicate nonverbally (e.g. gestures, facial expressions, pauses)

C461E69DE3484FEFB587469555E9DE6B.description: Compares forms of artistic expression by Spanish speakers with those of his/her own culture

DC911A7E2C5D4800A34BF15DFED633F6.description: Explores Spanish-language cultural outlets in his/her community (e.g. dance halls, restaurants, bookstores)

C34827D9EF5F4A14ABBBE81FC7BEBFEA.description: Expresses his/her opinion on works created by Spanish-speaking artists

133427DCF90740E295CA5ED5FDBC9ECC.description: Explores works created by Spanish-speaking artists (e.g. painting, sculpture, architecture)

6B2A21356612467A84D4464062B55825.description: Explores Spanish literary works or excerpts (e.g. comic books, young adult literature)

510FE59AC9C4491B8BC2C54F9CFA7A5D.description: Uses available Spanish-language media to improve his/her understanding of a subject or for entertainment purposes

F6B17DAA8B0D4D979A2EE1E49739EC5F.description: Explores different Spanish-language media (e.g. Web sites, magazines, television programs)

4FD66DA6D1CE41918CC55B3CCB1F08E1.description: Understands the meaning of Spanish-language songs

EEC30450AA214FD0B800A81B06FE41F9.description: Knows popular Spanish-language songs (e.g. Guantanamera, La Bamba, ¡Qué viva España!

B93E6474C6744B988433923E70FF1096.description: Familiarizes himself/herself with certain rhythms, songs and dances typical of Spanish-speaking societies (e.g. flamenco in Spain, salsa in Hispanic America)

3897A5E7B5984CF5819FD150F11FD003.description: Explores, by reading, listening to and viewing texts, sociohistorical similarities and differences between Québec culture and the cultures of Spanish-speaking countries

B962C722E6A14848A01A369DF1237FD0.description: Gives examples of the contribution of certain Spanish-speaking cultures to modern society (e.g. the discovery of the concept of the ordinal and cardinal zero by the Mayans)

600FD692D95149E5996FE577972866AE.description: Explains briefly the influence of certain social or historical events on Spanish-speaking societies (e.g. Free schooling in certain countries like Chile has raised the level of education. The colonization of certain countries like Mexico brought about the decline of spoken and written indigenous languages.)

3359A0E60E594CDD8DDB487BD1579031.description: Explains briefly the contributions of outstanding figures who have left their mark on the culture and society of various Spanish-speaking countries (e.g. Rigoberta Menchú and her fight for indigenous peoples’ rights)

5C52AB726AEC47899323B824325D94FE.description: Names public figures who have left their mark on past and present-day Spanish-speaking societies (e.g. Ernesto “Che” Guevara, a Marxist revolutionary; Juan Antonio Samaranch, President of the IOC for 21 years)

8692BD3D126C4D2B88955CE7E43CBA23.description: Gives examples of historical, tourist or archaeological sites associated with the culture of various Spanish-speaking countries (e.g. Machu Picchu, an old Inca city in Peru, dating from the XV century; the Alhambra, a major monument of Islamic architecture in Spain)

F857633757C04F5B8F7888B6496BF81D.description: Compares the economic situation of Spanish-speaking societies with that of Québec

7B7822D4B51C4BB98BD5F6A68C04D492.description: Explores economic developments that have influenced past and present-day Spanish-speaking societies (e.g. the demand for fair-trade products in North America has had positive impacts on the respect for the rights of Spanish American workers.)

1008ACE7A53D4F7F8BAD817BFBADD6A1.description: Compares the political context of Spanish-speaking countries with that of Québec

113702495F2E47A2B35D9B29C15EED21.description: Explores political events that have influenced past and present-day Spanish-speaking societies (e.g. Spain’s hegemony in the Spanish Golden Age, the advent of Communism in Cuba)

80B9F0DDE3424CC695D4F0B5CE21A386.description: Compares the education situation of young Spanish speakers with that of young Quebeckers

9011934D01EE442C8BF8DF595C4696AF.description: Explores elements of the education system in certain Spanish-speaking countries (e.g. number of years of mandatory schooling, functioning of elementary and secondary schools)

F34A998D79C44EFCA4087B15133A4D49.description: Explores aspects of Spanish-speaking cultures that allow some of their values to be compared with those in Québec culture (e.g. family or work relationships)

0B023421BF724077986F744B3ECE6E3B.description: Compares how various kinds of interpersonal relationships are viewed in Spanish-speaking societies and his/her own culture

71C1760BC8FB473B8A5B29844059F5EF.description: Explores typical aspects of relationships with government authorities in Spanish-speaking societies (e.g. distrust of the police, resignation in the face of bureaucratic red tape)

6506EEF65982495AA9B75E30E869ECE9.description: Explores typical aspects of workplace relationships in Spanish-speaking societies (e.g. great respect for one’s superior, increasingly egalitarian working relationships between men and women)

8FCEEB72AD544F8FA8BFA0BAB7F09CBA.description: Explores cultural aspects that influence interpersonal relationships in Spanish-speaking societies (e.g. the importance of family values, continuing prejudice against same-sex couples)

8230F13AC7254BCF880337F8C52CD5F2.description: Explores various types of social relationships in Spanish-speaking societies (e.g. lack of recognition for the rights of certain ethnic minorities, young people’s respect for older people)

815560560BE74B0981E1E57B8F11D230.description: Observes the traditional structure of Spanish-speaking families (e.g. the father as the authority figure) and other existing family structures (e.g. the mother as head of a single-parent family)

8E15DC761097457AAFB5FFED4186420F.description: Connects the standard of living in Spanish-speaking countries with the regional, social and cultural situations of these countries (e.g. Employees working in large tourist resorts are better paid than their counterparts in remote areas.)

D17614D40D0945789081B76F2984637D.description: Explores the influence of certain geographic features on the lifestyles of Spanish-speaking communities (e.g. a tropical climate favours an outdoor lifestyle)

3E462E4B583442B8AB84AE0CACAA75D8.description: Explores the living conditions in various Spanish-speaking countries (e.g. the main types of housing, social services provided by the government)

D9220290CAC040B2A255E469BB8D25AB.description: Integrates his/her knowledge of social and daily life practices in Spanish-speaking societies into his/her interactions and productions in Spanish

E045330B6B014E7CA427C0DD7F920E45.description: Explores manifestations of religious beliefs in Spanish-speaking societies (e.g. the presence of religious images and crucifixes in public buses, processions through the streets during Semana santa)

85969DD885904940833FCFE6B1E6264E.description: Recognizes certain customs and traditions particular to Spanish-speaking societies (e.g. la fiesta de quinceañera, which celebrates a woman’s passage from childhood to adulthood; las Fallas de Valencia, when giant artistic works are burned on the public square)

E28D1A4FDBB940EE8AB6C89F90617F85.description: Observes the concept of time in Spanish-speaking societies (e.g. the concept of punctuality implies tolerating lateness; work and school hours as well as mealtimes are not the same in Spanish America as they are in Spain)

61B2F513FE3448FC900480B093D24CC4.description: Compares certain characteristics of foods or eating habits in Spanish America, Spain and Québec

969398C661094551AB57A7A93E94E9B7.description: Observes eating habits in Spanish-speaking countries (e.g. foods of Spanish or SpanishAmerican origin, typical dishes, mealtimes)

8054A51820354A608F2A0B9EF398ECA8.description: Compares various activities of young Spanish speakers throughout the world with those of young Quebeckers (e.g. sports, hobbies, recreational pursuits)

BA10689FB3C149DC99844917DDB3B631.description: Uses Spanish, respecting its principal sociolinguistic conventions

DCFF4F411E994EEF8342207613F9DBD0.description: Understands certain forms of overt humour in Spanish (e.g. jokes, advertisements, riddles, puns)

9D595272799F412386A07CC5AF65C05D.description: Recognizes the influence of French (e.g. ballet, bechamel) or English (e.g. computadora, béisbol) on Spanish words

2FDFCC1AFF41411EA601A983E3C2593B.description: phonetic variations (e.g. the elision of the /s/ in the Caribbean or the aspiration of the /s/ in Central America, such as in the word estar, thus [e:tar] [e?tar])

8962FFA46C0249A58AC918AC28EC8E25.description: vocabulary (e.g. autobús in Spain, camión in Mexico, guagua in Cuba)

F399B62DCC7F4E9DA59C32602DAAD768.description: Uses the appropriate language register for the communication situation (e.g. formal when speaking to someone in a position of authority)

A334239DA2624A3CA4289377DBA6FE3C.description: formal (e.g. ¡Buenos días, señor Martínez! ¿Cómo se encuentra? / ¡Magnífico!)

2A11146A659F4CCFA0DE4401F828EA19.description: Recognizes the language register used by Spanish speakers in different communication situations:

D65FB0609A6F45B1BA282DF0A2279D92.description: Applies linguistic and paralinguistic conventions in a variety of communication situations

412BC186DFEC4419886A65C9FC8D0F9A.description: Recognizes linguistic and paralinguistic communication conventions used by Spanish speakers (e.g. addressing a person using the formal “you,” proximity during conversations)

AE613E80BC6A45AAA44D88274003C552.description: Uses the proper verb tense in simple or compound sentences (e.g. Me levanté a las siete esta mañana. / Hablaba con Rosa cuando José llegó.)

8583A75AA0454AE8ADF22D2AA3A99838.description: indicate necessity or obligation (e.g. Tenemos que marcharnos. / Hay que hacer deporte.)

29BDA574141F4329B2194895DDD373ED.description: describe an action at the moment it happens (e.g. Estoy haciendo mis deberes.)

2F36D5D4967A4395925F82CCBF0EAC81.description: refer to the imminence of the action (e.g. Voy a ver a mi abuela.)

5E582547A2E6424BA0A39212EC578F95.description: Distinguishes the value of the different verb tenses (e.g. the simple future locates an event in the future, the indicative imperfect (pretérito imperfecto del indicativo) describes an action of indeterminate length in the past, the simple past (pretérito indefinido) indicates an action that occurred at a precise moment in the past)

9A8876BF371043BAA2B61617CC3D8365.description: Valor y concordancia de tiempos verbales (Value of verb tenses and sequence of tenses)

A806384805C343ADB642F51561203B34.description: a gerund (e.g. Estoy cantando. / Está comiendo.)

DA7586EC021D4F12ACFEF9481BF92CD4.description: an infinitive (e.g. Vamos a pasear. / Tengo que ir. / Hay que caminar más rápido.)

066E819D9E8A4C51876E4ACF4CD8B01A.description: Recognizes the characteristics of a verbal periphrasis: it is composed of at least two verbs, the auxiliary and the main verb that takes the form of

3D68F8DE36C14F25B27F0E206F1558A0.description: the verb estar is used to indicate the location or condition, notably to describe a passing state or one connected to a circumstance (e.g. San Juan está en el centro de Costa Rica. / Los estudiantes están de buen humor hoy.)

7EE0502D380A4456915D5F2C8F349E7B.description: the verb ser is used to describe the inherent characteristics of the subject (e.g. Soy canadiense. / Las montañas son altas.)

2BE4E9863EE542D6989A76B6D2ACFA6D.description: Distinguishes between the use of the verb ser (to be) and estar (to be)

FDA63F5994C14CB6A72A97035B5E627B.description: in the present subjunctive (e.g. ser – sea)

08B7D2CA122647F3AA74A01D41D14879.description: in the simple future or present conditional (e.g. tener – tendré / poner – pondría)

FCFBBDCDA45F41F0A9B81EABC43EE91C.description: in the imperfect indicative, in the past perfect and in the simple past (e.g. ser ?era / escribir ?he escrito / tener ? tuve)

DDC6A8CA54E94AF0B52AA5B70B7BD61F.description: in the present indicative (e.g. conocer ? conozco / acostarse ? me acuesto)

AE2D2D1369884888A14EC20435028440.description: Knows the verb endings and how to conjugate regular verbs

D2E71C153C39436F9AB4B0605A13F894.description: the 3rd group includes verbs with infinitives ending in -ir (e.g. vivir)

F4BE18473AF149C7BCE4135BF616AEE1.description: the 2nd group includes verbs with infinitives ending in -er (e.g. comer)

1172FB8D58C74561918C54263127D4D9.description: the 1st group includes verbs with infinitives ending in -ar (e.g. hablar)

8BAA0882A2044718A2F82CF114EAE01B.description: Knows the three groups of regular verbs

E969B88E79804EC7A4F35E49B243A4BB.description: is composed of the auxiliary verb “to have” (haber) followed by a past participle for compound tenses (e.g. he jugado, había caído)

D9287717D718446CB9C0708259CADC51.description: is a pronominal verb when conjugated with a reflexive pronoun (e.g. levantarse, me ducho, están vistiéndose)

B6A75F5B3A444BE3A25636FC0583B411.description: is composed of a stem, which expresses the meaning, and an ending, which in simple tenses designates the mood, tense, person and number (e.g. nosotros leemos, ellos leían)

3E13DA7D924149A1A00D637F5285877A.description: is conjugated and varies in mood (e.g. indicative, subjunctive), in tense (e.g. present, past), in person (e.g. third person) and in number

7DE1CBEA94254A33B0D8B3E0DB7A6C05.description: may be preceded by no (e.g. No puedo tocar la guitarra.)

2FB2897C40214978901DC60512A393B5.description: Recognizes the characteristics of a verb

0CD0C02E14244801B1644BE8B4C4CB99.description: conjunctions are invariable (e.g. Nos gustaría ir pero no podemos.)

1883B4BABCCE4D698438BC0A31A6E4B1.description: the subordinating conjunction allows a subordinate clause to be inserted into another clause (e.g. Iré si me invitas. / No me preocupa que lleguen tan tarde.)

552BD85CB3864AD1B831D601D862D74C.description: the coordinating conjunction allows groups of independent phrases or clauses to be joined together (e.g. Vi a Pedro y a Juan. / Nos quedaremos en casa o iremos al cine.)

A2CD96EE78794966934A9FFB4ABBBACD.description: Recognizes the characteristics of a coordinating conjunction (e.g. pero, y) or a subordinating conjunction (e.g. que, porque, si)

EBC6356DADB747C783C272A1604E8B7F.description: Recognizes the main characteristic of a prepositional phrase: it is composed of two or more words that form an indivisible unit (e.g. a causa de, de acuerdo con)

E2042E55A54345CB907BD3541878D19C.description: Knows the normal use of the prepositions por and para (e.g. Andan por la calle. / Este regalo es para ti.)

81DC20A58808436491DDB8A341642AE5.description: is invariable (e.g. Los libros están sobre las mesas.)

1197774A79B64F57BE22F50CA4A81965.description: is always followed by an expansion (e.g. Estamos al lado de ellos.)

AE01B31DCE58482283E3C448912C9826.description: Recognizes the characteristics of a preposition

28B37BC98E5F4ABD973C828ED8274E74.description: Recognizes the various classifications of adverbs (e.g. of place ? aquí, of time ? hoy, of mood ? mejor, of quantity ? mucho, of affirmation – también, of negation ? tampoco)

CD53688AE9904EA59690F120ADC3C071.description: adverbs ending in -mente are formed from the feminine of the adjective (e.g. lenta / lentamente)

179F81C7A2144B18815E09D88285F9B2.description: may be simple or compound (e.g. bastante, poco a poco)

D282CD43659E492786CC6FD0E0445431.description: is invariable (e.g. Están extremadamente contentos. / Corre rápidamente.)

2CD7377BB12144CEBD57E1C4F10733A5.description: Recognizes the characteristics of an adverb

932E9C249ECE4421A4B8C04F6FA378A7.description: Recognizes the form of certain pronouns that vary in person (e.g. yo, tú), gender (e.g. él, ella), number (e.g. le, ustedes), gender and number (e.g. el mío, esas) or that never vary (e.g. contigo, nadie)

939B95D6D23E474098A75036A70E1FB1.description: indefinite pronoun (e.g. Nadie escucha. / Alguien viene.)

888FA55CA32543888C12C51AE9965995.description: interrogative and exclamatory pronoun (e.g. ¿Quién quiere responder? ¿Cómo te llamas?)

566444388F3443B5AF054D44E33B1FCB.description: possessive pronoun (e.g. El mío está aquí. / Los suyos son cómodos.)

CCD8377060664B0DAEA8DACFBF54A76C.description: demonstrative pronoun (e.g. Este es lujoso. / Esa es difícil. / Aquel es original. / Esto es muy simple.)

4F253A3897DE444D9A6E78F06C43DD4E.description: relative pronoun (e.g. El chico que vino es mi primo. / Ese es un concepto con el cual puedo estar de acuerdo.)

404377FFB7AD43A7B9659A474947B823.description: object with preposition (e.g. La camisa es para mí. / Yo hice el trabajo contigo.)

19427F39A703469EB4A6E43AC6A16C34.description: direct or indirect object without a preposition (e.g. Me lo compro. / A él, le gusta comer patatas fritas. / Me levanto tarde.)

27875C3ACBD0448CA4B9B374F705166C.description: subject or object (e.g. Yo vivo en Sevilla. / Yo no soy tú.)

8149C03BD6634C5CB7442EF3B1CAC26A.description: replaces a syntactic group or a phrase (e.g. En cuanto a mi hermana, la veré mañana.)

0A10CEF4444A4433A60F60D3BEF6DFC1.description: may be placed before or after a verb (e.g. Me gusta el chocolate / Es el mío. / Termina de vestirse.)

6218A2C0397D46A8AC624E3E6BD394D2.description: if it is the subject of the verb, the personal pronoun is used only to avoid ambiguity (e.g. Yo hablo. / Hablo.)

EC457CD2FB6C4F8B939798FB559B492F.description: Recognizes the characteristics of a pronoun

BBC6FB9E05F94D2AB99EDBD144E144F9.description: the determiner cuál is invariable in gender but agrees in number with the noun to which it is connected (e.g. ¿Cuáles son tus deportes favoritos?)

DDA5E0EB665F47F5A5733FA24417E1A8.description: precedes the name (e.g. ¿Qué libro has leído?)

EAB3D14FA05D47F1B933B6B10869D2E2.description: Recognizes the characteristics of an interrogative and exclamatory determiner (e.g. qué,cuál)

010BF588B9744CCD9A1F432183ADDE29.description: an ordinal number agrees in gender and number with the noun to which it is connected (e.g. las primeras civilizaciones)

B79F1CE2DB8546CD9FBF67B73C7A3877.description: a cardinal number is invariable in gender and in number (e.g. cuatro linternas)

0295AE8D2D96493E82C46528355712FF.description: precedes the noun (e.g. catorce chicos, la cuarta calle)

58AD0CCE8C5A4B65B47DE2CF035AB109.description: Recognizes the characteristics of a cardinal number (e.g. uno, dos, tres) and an ordinal number (e.g. primero, segundo, tercero)

85EB9E0073C2469D9B66876992CF0381.description: takes the gender and number of the noun to which it is connected (e.g. nuestra cultura, los vecinos tuyos)

3503C54B8D0947B09024CBD7EA544DBF.description: may take the postnominal form (e.g. el libro mío, el coche tuyo, la rosa suya)

3C64AB0B4B564BB296EB531259FE8DBD.description: may take the pronominal form in apocopate form (e.g. mi reloj, tu armario, su novio)

F93DEA8757EB4FFAA013AE1765B53391.description: Recognizes the characteristics of a possessive determiner

3730E4254D714961B4F19EC992657612.description: takes the gender and number of the noun to which it is linked (e.g. Estos peces son blancos.)

E8EF5832226A4206ACA3B971E55C6189.description: depends on the position of the subject in space and in time in relation to the speaker and the audience (e.g. Esta casa es bonita. Esa casa es bonita. Aquella casa es bonita.)

0394B8CD920142AC94DC13C7F2EDFB43.description: precedes the noun (e.g. Este señor es abogado.)

F245FA177AA740E3902CBEF45CA3F56C.description: Recognizes the characteristics of a demonstrative determiner

5AD6487A064B453D98611FEF48169CAE.description: the article el is contracted when it is preceded by the prepositions a or de (e.g. [a el] mercado ? al mercado, [de el]?del jardín)

3D2F99641360489F83B14BF309C71960.description: the indefinite article un or una is not used in front of nouns referring to a profession, a nationality or a religion (e.g. Es maestra. / Eres peruano. / Soy católica.)

B6D2AFCF24A741219D8D5D10A9A958A7.description: takes the gender and number of the noun to which it is linked (e.g. el caballo, unas zanahorias); there are a few exceptions (e.g. un alma, el hambre)

2478D058AFCE420E8C439E7E123EE003.description: is never preceded by any other determiners except todo (e.g. todas las mañanas)

DA5CF02CC5C34368A4A82085A68637A4.description: precedes a noun (e.g. la casa, un gato)

7D67CE7FD0034475ADA4F07A26D9E4B1.description: Recognizes the characteristics of a definite article (e.g. el, la, los, las) and an indefinite article (un, una, unos, unas)

DA32AA33B4134B219CDBC36C10F89543.description: Applies the rules for forming the feminine and the plural of adjectives during his/her interactions or in his/her oral or written productions

67CAAC4CBE9C405BBFCA8FA2A494A6BA.description: addition of -es to adjectives ending in a consonant (e.g. fácil / fáciles)

97B190CBC3E04D288E3927325E571175.description: addition of -s to adjectives ending in a vowel (e.g. inteligente / inteligentes)

E18D9E733A504D5D8D25CAC1CF5B7A70.description: Knows the rules for forming the plural of adjectives

4BF9FF579FF34D02A6292338A59BCE65.description: addition of -a to the masculine form of the adjective when it ends in -or, -on, -és (e.g. trabajadora, burlona, inglesa)

58FF2C1B867C49B88C81DE65BBC94FF8.description: replacement of the -o of the masculine form with an -a to create the feminine form (e.g. feo / fea)

B57092CF68444592B0A698F163569F23.description: Knows the rules for forming the feminine of adjectives

777CD694E8E844FD810085DBF9E519C0.description: may be invariable in gender (e.g. el coche verde, la planta verde)

C362C8658E8C4F39A86C5C0C0F3CDF8F.description: generally varies in gender and in number (e.g. Las cometas naranjas y amarillas revolotean en el cielo.)

68B0E1CEE9294E4AA65B5DAD9B3417CE.description: usually placed after a noun in a noun phrase (e.g. Los zapatos negros son bonitos.) or after a link verb (e.g. Es muy simpática.)

04316E040D844BCD9119AD3EFBED6616.description: Recognizes the characteristics of an adjective

D133CB64A27346578D1CDB00A3D28B8F.description: Applies the rules for forming the plural of nouns during his/her interactions or in his/her oral or written productions

EC765854D2F44EB1BF860BCB36A0E824.description: Recognizes invariable nouns (e.g. el or los lunes / la or las crisis)

35BEE52D2AF341BF8E61C6D86758A6ED.description: Knows the exceptions to the rules for forming the plural of nouns (e.g. el pez / los peces, el irani / los iranies)

5D35F01E10B1425DAA82016BB3298211.description: adding an -es to nouns ending in a consonant (e.g. los papeles, las canciones)

20B90A5EE78C453A88D019DB2D3EAC57.description: adding an -s to nouns ending in a vowel (e.g. los amigos, las manzanas)

A0D5FE9462374722B47EB4ED383CD9D5.description: Knows the rules for forming the plural of nouns

9498565BF00B40FCABF106086E0C7678.description: Knows the exceptions to the rules regarding the gender of nouns (e.g. la mano, el poeta, el arroz)

8F59ADC01C294E3B864BA16BFB08CA45.description: feminine nouns usually end in -a, -ción, -tad, -dad, -umbre (e.g. la señora, la estación, la libertad, la calidad, la cumbre)

D84E3372CEF449C6A60F5366186467EC.description: masculine nouns usually end in -o, -an, -or, -ma (e.g. el banco, el pan, el color, el problema)

7856F0B1713A43B399166A005E902639.description: Recognizes the gender of nouns by their ending

774989C7F4AE4778938D22773F851CB8.description: a proper noun starts with a capital letter (e.g. La ciudad de Barcelona es magnífica.)

55201C93E9B44871B1E0DA923EF91AF0.description: a common noun is preceded by a determiner (e.g. una silla, un hombre)

8DEC6C7B4037477D8A62427DA994CDE9.description: Recognizes the characteristics of a noun

20585FC461DF42E398AC225F67E76387.description: indirect object of the verb (e.g. Elisa da un regalo a Rosa.)

6B99705BA5DD43A6ACA87ABDC808D4FF.description: direct object of the verb (e.g. Veo a Marta.)

87DF2D02BBFE47A19D9F2804A6FD62E5.description: noun complement (e.g. la bandera de Chile)

14A0FA67049D4204AB9EC6D96980C83F.description: Recognizes the function of a prepositional phrase

DC4CAAC8977241349096C451EA30AEAB.description: Use expansion to clarify the meaning of a preposition

3F94E41D191C4B14B23614B16B83E770.description: Recognizes that a prepositional phrase is composed of a preposition followed by a compulsory expansion (e.g. en el armario, según él, para siempre)

EB4A5D64915445E5AA6378FB25D8193F.description: modification of a verb, adjective and adverb (e.g. camina rápidamente, realmente fácil, poco después)

BD4566CD8CC447159C9B5536D274C0EA.description: verb complement (e.g. Estaremos de vacaciones mañana.)

01C791EA7C6443F0AB92973DC1944B99.description: Recognizes the function of an adverbial phrase

A118211CA5A64A8C9A74D568A4BC2448.description: Uses expansion to clarify the meaning of an adverb

41FCDAE9BECB4663BFA3B1EBFEA5279F.description: Recognizes an expansion in an adverbial phrase (e.g. afortunadamente para él, lo más despacio posible)

7F5E2DF0935D4056B3A3B2AB3F081DDD.description: Recognizes the core (nucleo) of an adverbial phrase: an adverb (e.g. Viven lejos de la ciudad.)

388D8B9472A648EFB5D2EEC7A6FF44DF.description: two or more noun phrases linked by a coordinate or pronouns of different persons (e.g. Mi hermano y mi primo estudian en la misma escuela. / Tú y yo pensamos igual.)

9700C83181C54DB0B09A89F9CF27AEF0.description: a noun phrase, whether placed before or after the verb (e.g. España ganó la copa mundial de fútbol. / A ella, le fascinan los animales exóticos.)

2DBBA0BBE8BE40B199EB5E544A749960.description: Makes the verb agree in number and person with the subject

116C33C872CB4CACBDFD97A581AB848F.description: in number and person with the subject (e.g. [Ustedes] escriben.)

DC89EB84FB214C6C9C7A22F252263035.description: Recognizes that the verb must agree

FC3EBB8AC4DD4C8181AD096DCEDA81F4.description: Recognizes the function of a verb phrase: sentence predicate (e.g. El profesor explica la lección a los alumnos.)

B7B9A231A4224DE08ACF1F3418508E54.description: Uses expansion to clarify the meaning of a verb

C8612F8FD5AB4CF7A912D5C750929F42.description: Recognizes an expansion in a verb phrase (e.g. Esteban está enfermero. / Están tristes. / Carlos entrega su examen. / Jacinta habla con sus padres. / Alejandro quiere comer pollo. / [Nosotros] nos levantamos temprano. / Vivo aquí.)

78112693A0D545AAA13E81E0E6B0F702.description: Recognizes the core (nucleo) of a verb phrase: a conjugated verb (e.g. La señora baila la bachata.)

22066FB34EC947ECA6C04C15D732EDBE.description: attribute of the subject (e.g. Estos libros son rojos.)

1D009D83A18243BEBC05C878D95F3237.description: noun complement (e.g. Tienen tres hijos muy hermosos.)

61D21D18AD42492DA893F91B1A50A608.description: Recognizes the function of an adjectival phrase

05D2A060D6BD48F2BBE28E72F3F7602C.description: Uses expansion to clarify the meaning of an adjective

5C55334D4A00471E8DC5214930363693.description: Recognizes an expansion in an adjectival phrase (e.g. menos limpio, tan guapo como tú, amable con ella, contenta de verte)

ABB9F0AB1A5348AC82575F76F8297232.description: Recognizes the core (nucleo) of an adjectival phrase: an adjective (e.g. Es una calle muy ruidosa.

EB67086D43C04138AD9C4871C23B211C.description: the adjective placed before or after the noun

1300D08E8E684BA29D40836B5BA38DD9.description: Makes the following agree in gender and in number with the noun

7E51A384AEEE4E21BF18A12B6E1738A7.description: the adjectives placed before or after the noun (e.g. un gran barco, un partido aburrido)

7482554AFEBD48F9B36790B7D2825221.description: the determiner (e.g. una muchacha, un cuaderno)

7F6A3C5FCFA4430B94437CFA3C882D44.description: Recognizes the noun as the word with which the following must agree

5F18937307D04E37B4C56E83E8CDA7F4.description: verb complement (e.g. Tomo el autobús todos los días con mis amigos.)

AB102ADC964140DF8B94E05A4E4C0607.description: direct object of the verb (e.g. Construye un edificio. / Lo construye.)

A7565B5DB4C342BCB7FBE353AD0B5DF0.description: noun complement (e.g. El ataque del enemigo)

FF344172682B49CD8A327492201B5811.description: subject of the sentence (e.g. Los turistas canadienses visitan el Museo Mural Diego Rivera.)

9EAD02A003EA4666800575160181ECD5.description: Recognizes the functions of a noun phrase

ECD75E977CAF45939E2407FF28155D50.description: Uses expansion to clarify the meaning of the core of the noun phrase

E24E3BB450744460AF033E6B3E509989.description: Recognizes an expansion in a noun phrase (e.g. aire frío / un viaje a Mallorca / el Museo Nacional Centro de Arte Reina Sofía / una casa muy lejos de aquí)

E9A468D0CD424F71A082B3A3126CB9E7.description: Recognizes the core (nucleo) of a noun phrase: a noun or pronoun (e.g. Ricardo estudia el español. / Un pez nada en el río. / Él es guapo. / Esto es interesante.)

5548BE77B9A94F91AF7124D5FF95FD8D.description: Joins clauses by using subordination, employing the proper conjunction

C6A7BF7A58254B0DAADC05A81A4247C0.description: Recognizes subordinate clauses by the subordinate conjunctions (e.g. Llego tarde porque había tráfico.)

13FCD43EF06C4C93842D56AA6A7D71EF.description: Juxtaposes or coordinates clauses by using the proper punctuation or conjunction

57420CEC88D24D30B2213623A02873DF.description: Recognizes the use of coordinating conjunctions to connect independent clauses (e.g. Me gusta hacer deporte pero hoy voy a descansar.)

3A8582D48B2245A7933F0D14B65DED91.description: Recognizes the use of the comma, semicolon or colon to juxtapose independent clauses within the same sentence (e.g. Por la mañana, Pedro se despierta, se levanta, se ducha y desayuna.)

A3C78BE7057242B1AA8D996F2268F699.description: implicit subject is in the third person singular (e.g. Nieva mucho.)

5AD378AEDC7C41D4AFC37BCE24EF0DC0.description: use of verbs such as haber and hacer (e.g. Hay muchos alumnos. Hace calor.)

D3D5989FDD324012BF4D4C1188918678.description: Recognizes the characteristics of the impersonal sentence

818715DB0F734EBD927C51C34A76E145.description: the direct object of the verb is placed in the subject position in the sentence and the subject is placed in the position of the object of the passive verb (e.g. La celebración ha sido organizada por mi tía.)

9031E477315C45CD844F3FFF3676A97B.description: Recognizes the characteristics of the passive-voice sentence

0C6BCA74708F4DC3B59A60508307B161.description: an indefinite determiner is used without the adverb no

7D606770398C4B09BD11C99C67EC8E8D.description: a negative adverb is used without the adverb no

EB400DF9CDF548D7AD71AE65CD935794.description: another adverb is used with the adverb no

1B443174BD3042A5BF2E033F3C06E5DF.description: the adverb no is placed in front of the verb

1DA6E7ACFDA04E50A6F5F389FB2A06CC.description: Produces a negative sentence in which

07A9FA5B96704E858385149A85FB485A.description: use of the conjunction ni (e.g. Ni tú ni yo sabemos la respuesta.)

1D601D1B5331493F8C311A50FF6A4043.description: use of an indefinite determiner (e.g. Ningún alumno entendió la explicación.)

D4AD18181E2643CA8958E5F185C3D6A3.description: use of a negative adverb other than no (e.g. Jamás lo haré.)

44E97F7ACAE14D21929BF142A892D096.description: use of the adverb no and a second adverb (e.g. No voy nunca al teatro.)

75D89DCA81B740FA9ED74ED5066B9685.description: use of the adverb no before the verb (e.g. Mateo no practica el futbol.)

BD47953267D743989CC26278620863B5.description: Recognizes the characteristics of the negative sentence

57E3003E3CA848CAAEA49FC03399E910.description: the second grammatical person (tú, vos, vosotros), the second person addressed (usted, ustedes) and the first grammatical person plural (nosotros) are used to conjugate the verb but do not appear in the sentence (e.g. ¡Salgamos de aquí!)

A282195B181246E08B2840312362526E.description: the verb is in the imperative mood (e.g. Venga por aquí.)

F81EE47E08C644AFB417A0324B36CF59.description: Recognizes the characteristics of an imperative sentence

2F2A5C78377048CF94A824C88ECEDA1D.description: Recognizes the main characteristic of an exclamatory sentence: an inverted exclamation point at the beginning of the sentence and an exclamation point at the end of the sentence (e.g. ¡Estoy aquí!)

3A842A592FA04D86ACEDC372813CDF41.description: an interrogative word at the beginning of the sentence

901F0AD2A7D14C26A17B8CD167171142.description: Produces an interrogative sentence that includes

E914521F9A144392B11B263C638C1E78.description: inversion (or not) of the subject and verb (e.g. ¿Es Antonio de Barcelona? ¿Antonio es de Barcelona?)

32C893CA2BA54C7F8249307F698BDAF0.description: an interrogative word at the beginning of the sentence (e.g. ¿Qué estudias?)

1BC3FFC9151349A6A6D77C38F6310470.description: an inverted question mark at the beginning of the sentence and a question mark at the end of the sentence (e.g. ¿Vas a ir al cine?)

098826ED148F426385B85AD1D9A2BCFB.description: Recognizes the characteristics of an interrogative sentence

9D61E8DB2EC040B6A6AACA8D488E1F79.description: a subject consisting of a noun phrase and a predicate consisting of a verb and one or more complements

33E111527E5446C7902D30AFE3C448C7.description: a subject consisting of a noun or pronoun and a predicate consisting of a verb

28763618111344E3BCC40F89A0FD9574.description: Formulates a one clause sentence that contains

A5997332135747919772EA2E31F1B8C7.description: verb phrase that contains the sentence’s main conjugated verb and one or more objects or complement (e.g. El maestro canta una canción con sus alumnos.

06CFA1A700FB4594BA5944C50FC4BA3E.description: Recognizes the form that the predicate takes in a sentence

A3EEBA8B74CB4678A7D384EAFCA27A89.description: noun phrase (e.g. El perro negro ladra mucho. / Los amigos de mi primo corren.)\

A9CCAD0AD8FF4AD98A99E7692F259918.description: Recognizes the form that the subject takes in a sentence

77136E22790246E292F51007CB309E19.description: contains two main parts: a subject and a predicate (e.g. Los estudiantes / ven una película.)

ED33961B07B14B7EB27416797D5E0785.description: Recognizes the characteristics of a one clause sentence

2B0929B3E9C445C59E03B4279171EFDD.description: Substitutes a word or group of words with one of the following:

5D949C767C90422A856CA36B7BFEC7A8.description: an object pronoun (e.g. Javier tiene un diccionario. Lo lleva a clase todos los días.)

1F32615E64754EC9AC9CFBFD93BEAE38.description: a generic or specific term (e.g. Ana come una manzana. Le gusta mucho esta fruta roja.)

8D8024C8F566418B96CE999C488479C1.description: a determiner (e.g. María se compró una casa. Su casa es bonita.)

E047DBFCCEE34390A3FDC754E2BC4C86.description: a subject pronoun (e.g. José es bajo. Él tiene pelo rubio.)

3B4A932000DF4992BD087BB405213FE8.description: Identifies in a text the substitution of a word or group of words with one of the following:

D8ECA9C185DA4913BFBB35DCC29BB634.description: Connects ideas by using relation markers (e.g. primero, sin embargo, a continuación)

9D7FFBAA5C3B4D3DAC987AE9B991B66B.description: Produces a text in which the information flows from one paragraph to the next (e.g. In a narrative text, each paragraph deals with a new element.)

13ED9AAE283E46F4B8308B3C7034EFDB.description: Interacts or produces a text in which the information flows from one sentence to the next

66132846A7E74311B4C807A8DAFC269E.description: Interacts or produces an oral or written text, staying on topic

BF70E26AF232421FBB7B855144D4D2C7.description: Produces short texts of various types, both oral and written

DA8F78337F184EF8AB9AE21ADC98DDDB.description: tell a story (e.g. comic strip, story)

DAB96BBB4BA14BBC8B1EBFEB444F91C2.description: Recognizes text type of oral or written texts whose purpose is to

61F987C356934BD8AD8740CAD3A6F300.description: Uses the intonation appropriate to the sentence type

87EB5DA629CB41D896FE52F4F8E16FFC.description: exclamatory sentence and rising, then falling, intonation (e.g. ¡Duerme tranquilo!)

93C33F582A0C450DB9CB58A08D7F76CB.description: interrogative sentence and rising intonation (e.g. ¿Duerme tranquilo?)

5911195B152944E6A8623EF2DB61BB61.description: declarative sentence and falling intonation (e.g. Duerme tranquilo.)

C1056C7389C04FB8972FCBB7C7732C21.description: Speaks sentences in rhythmic groups, including pauses as required

22BD53A047694A9F90CDDA1C80D203D8.description: Knows the rhythmic groups and how to accentuate the syllables of words in a statement (e.g. En verano, / cuando estoy de vacaciones, / me gusta bañarme y jugar al tenis.)

450A83A14E1F413AA2D045E336BB16C0.description: links the words correctly when speaking

DA8DCA91F8B34C0AA1D1AC265D0C1DBF.description: knows how two identical vowels or consonants are linked (e.g. la casa azul – la casaazul, mi hijo – mihijo, esos señores – esosseñores)

F169BB8C152D4AAAB34D72CC51257152.description: links the words correctly when speaking

9484C9F977EE43F881BDE37D19DC3B7E.description: knows the process of linking two different vowels or a consonant followed by a vowel (e.g. mi amigo – mi amigo, sin embargo – sin embargo)

3466D5BF1A354677BB951BF35063EB3E.description: Pronounces the stressed syllable in a word correctly

0BD70E434A74427DB2FED7FDA74D522D.description: Recognizes that the stress can vary depending on the meaning of a word (e.g. canto – song, cantó – I sang; el – the / él – he)

F1D43C404EB0492FA49BC37A2B41CBB8.description: the final syllable when the word ends in a consonant other than n or s (e.g. profesor, hotel)

36E448C03D6642A5B5CB72A835DCFACF.description: the penultimate syllable when the word ends in a vowel, an n or an s (e.g. amigo, comen, casas)

B53C833B78514163B1936D291A75AA4B.description: the syllable that has an orthographic accent (e.g. México, pájaro)

B7D3C2D7231A48E2BD77E47F9CE7B366.description: Recognizes that, in the spoken language, the tonic accent is on

EF07A41A0F854E1D87DA26F72ECF7544.description: pronounces adjacent phonemes that affect the meaning of words correctly (e.g. pero [pe?o] and perro [pero]; lama [lama] and llama [?ama]; ano [ano] and año [a?o])

D1A3C02FC0BE4437A30CF0A294188027.description: recognizes and pronounces consonant phonemes correctly (e.g. pala [pala], bala [bala], mala [mala], sala [sala], año [a?o], ano [ano])

86EC9506A7DB44858AFF8348BC34F656.description: recognizes and pronounces diphthongs correctly (e.g. causa [kausa], duerme [du?rme], peine [peine])

5BF7B9B85D984608AF3D0474859F42AC.description: recognizes and pronounces the hiatus correctly (e.g. tí?o [ti:o], Ra-úl [ra:ul], cre-o [cre:o])

DE7D222075AD44B1997E435740EFFA6D.description: recognizes and pronounces vowel phonemes correctly (e.g. paso [paso], peso [peso], piso [piso], poso [poso], puso [puso])

B686224C7BBC4D35A2AD137D3B6E39D9.description: Establishes a connection between the letters of the alphabet and the sounds they produce (e.g. papa [papa], casa [kasa], queso [keso], kiosco [kiosko], beso [beso], vaca [baka], Wagner [bagn?r], hada [ada], estudiante [?studjante])

31CD354548914805AEA108524B4CB086.description: Recognizes that the same word can have different meanings depending on the context (e.g. contar dinero ? to count money, contar una historia ? to tell a story, contar con alguien ? to rely on someone)

5F82FFE28BB243A0A138EDDD596D7315.description: certain words that are generally used only with certain other words (e.g. el vino tinto and not el sombrero tinto, una rebanada de pan and not una rebanada de mantequilla)

A93D2383D2FC496B8EF108B339081BA8.description: two words with the same pronunciation but different meanings (e.g. the homophones el ? the, él ? he / varón ? man, barón ? baron / tuvo ? he had, tubo ? tube)

74F9CB431F164D7DB188D16B879E0ACF.description: two words that have the same spelling but different meanings (e.g. the homonyms como – I eat, como – like / sobre – envelope, sobre - on)

F11B79ACB49E4DEBABE87C19783DEDAB.description: a generic term and a specific term (e.g. the hypernym fruta and the hyponym plátano)

E6C97EF1E5974309882BF0501C5768A3.description: two words with opposite meanings (e.g. the antonyms antes / después, la pregunta / la respuesta, mínimo / máximo)

28092161F6A643199A4ECDC6F1F23D67.description: two words with the same meaning (e.g. the synonyms volver / regresar, el pelo / el cabello, jamás / nunca)

DA51EB488A504FCAB4FD76E01642F514.description: words from the same lexical field (e.g. el vendedor, los recuerdos, el precio, el regateo to talk about el mercado)

B30948FE60FF484C8EE9F058925C7AC8.description: words from the same family (e.g. comer, comida, comedor, comilón)

505E32057CEE432499046FA605391C0E.description: words from the same family (e.g. comer, comida, comedor, comilón)

C4A6A7256E1344E08D48BB34ECB7DF36.description: Places accents in the correct places in the words that he/she has learned (e.g. cafetería, marrón, Perú)

A1B64E22910B434EA4E7D396E01ADB6C.description: Capitalizes words correctly (e.g. in proper names, in titles)

3254FA499DBC4A1F9EE628060DA8EE44.description: Spells correctly the words that he/she has learned

FDCE5BFD8B524A52B0DB945291D4B984.description: Identifies words created by compounding (e.g. lavaplatos, medianoche, pintalabios)

B0DBC351685447C6904B49AF10F51E1E.description: Understands the meaning of certain prefixes and suffixes (e.g. the negative or lack of (in-), as in indiscreto; a profession (-or), as in director; a place (-ería), as in panadería)

13D0A3FA05064CF9AFA9012B51667DF6.description: adding a suffix (e.g. comedor, rojizo, rápidamente)

91D0A623E861464FB91D6C1BE03A5317.description: adding a prefix (e.g. sobrenombre, rehacer, imposible, abajo)

1B2183F9771243E6AA96611A48750447.description: Identifies the derivation process for building words

781218DAAB5E406790E7B6DEFF109994.description: Identifies the root to which a prefix or a suffix has been added (e.g. incómodo, casita)

0CA5219A74244CE5ACDD618365ECDFD2.description: Uses idiomatic expressions acquired by listening to, reading or viewing texts

B5839241FBEE4791B6C26B6A3197840F.description: Understands idiomatic expressions when listening to, reading or viewing texts (e.g. ¡Caramba! which means “Oh dear!”; ¡Qué rico! which means “That’s so good!”; hablar de uno a sus espaldas which means “to talk about someone behind his/her back”)

F12AAA882140460B9CCE852C4BAEDC31.description: Understands the literal and figurative meanings of certain words when listening to, reading or viewing texts (e.g. llevar puestos unos pantalones to describe what someone is wearing and llevar bien puestos los pantalones to describe the authority exercised by someone)

50EEED9C22CA4A27A0EC9D14B7D87419.description: Uses the vocabulary learned during his/her interactions and productions

438A50DCB2CE4121B83F0E2E1D01696A.description: Understands common vocabulary related to the topic under discussion (e.g. el viaje, la reproducción, las estaciones, los países to discuss the migration of the Monarch butterfly)

8D253876675F4A9CA06811057B287821.description: Uses vocabulary related to the expression of personal, educational or social needs

4EA1726DB5ED481A9032E5997E48EE02.description: Understands vocabulary related to the expression of personal, educational or social needs (e.g. expresses his/her preferences and feelings, follows instructions, formulates requests)

EC4F9351935E4F2AAA5B32F9A505BB56.description: Uses basic vocabulary related to his/her immediate environment

DB1506D2E5D2468C973BB95D08B3B6E3.description: Understands basic vocabulary related to his/her immediate environment (e.g. the classroom, school, home)

749B823D7DA540DBAFFFB8FA21BB50FC.description: Recognizes that a text can have more than one communicative purpose (e.g. a protest song that entertains and calls for action)

859B6FF109064DFA883634226459178C.description: Recognizes that different oral or written texts can serve the same communicative purpose (e.g. an advertisement or an editorial to provoke an action or reaction)

428C862C600344169E82B82E69E89D29.description: Adopts a communicative purpose for his/her interactions and oral and written productions (e.g. to be informed) and adheres to it

5BC2CFB2F5D24928B02A4936D19E907E.description: speaker (e.g. the speaker or writer wants to inform someone else)

D8991BAB649F437498CA4B21967E75B9.description: audience (e.g. the listener or reader wants to inform himself/herself)

B027EBFE4ED34C41A53AA7E0FD425A39.description: Identifies the communicative purpose(s) of the

F58AB5EDA27944E29B0574B777438F3C.description: to evaluate and self-evaluate (e.g. expresses a doubt, compares his/her situation with that of others)

76739AB5C4E84F9BAA5C9BA62B472F5C.description: to entertain or have fun (e.g. plays with words, sings a song)

E58FECC9DC204C2F84241BB1730BB4F4.description: to persuade to act or react (e.g. provides advice, proposes a solution)

D75B36CA19C64715A0B1F71DCB9B7C36.description: to inform or be informed (e.g. requests or provides an explanation; describes or explains a fact)

ADC422DB11B54E8F833E0EF68B64FBF9.description: to express (e.g. expresses a need or an emotion)

B4211EAC80B5431D88F92302C6D1C0A1.description: to initiate communication, maintain contact (e.g. introduces himself/herself or another person, requests assistance)

50EEC07B06614C6BA8E7484A4473E846.description: Recognizes the main communicative purposes and examples of language productions

FC0BDF7D03A645CC9F48ED2E4DB146E4.description: Uses his/her knowledge of the elements of the communication situation to better understand a text and to support his/her interactions or oral or written work (e.g. adapts his/her message to the characteristics of the audience or their reactions)

5491C53FF20742AD8EB668B841E09D30.description: Recognizes how certain characteristics of one or more elements of the communication situation influence the others (e.g. the type and form of the speaker’s message varies, depending on his/her relationship with the audience.)

44EA48512D854DB2BA8663BF60BDD540.description: Recognizes the elements of the communication situation: speaker, audience, context, message, code and communication medium
